div1.p: Truby emphasizes how important Lazear's lost notebook is. He believes it is in the hands of the Carroll family.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, February 11, 1946
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Feb. 11/46
Dear Colonel Hench:-
div1.p:
I was pleased to get your
letter of Dec. 31. It contained so much
info. of interest to me, as well as
the news about your activities. It must
seem good to get back to your old
home and to your work at the clinic.
However, no matter how much you have
been put out by your army experience,
you will eventually look back on it
with pleasure and feel, too, that it
was worth while. I do hope you will
eventually clear up some of the real
problems of your specialty, and that your
work in the army has aided in solving
them.

I was glad to hear of the Keans, Irelands,
Reeds and others. Wish I could have
been at the Hotel Staller dinner too.
Of course, I was much interested in
what you said about your paranoid friend--
Carroll. I am confident that he has the
AC
T
Lazear note book & other papers that
should have been left by his father in
his lab. at the Army Med. School. That is where
Reed left them. Years ago, either Ireland or
Kean, told me that “The Lazear note book
mysteriously disappeared afterat Carroll's death”
I hope you will be able to get someone;
like Mr. C.L. Reed, who can succede in
getting things from Carroll. The notebook
in probably the only thing of value, but any
of Reed's letters would contain important
data. I do hope to see that note book and
see how near right I have been in
my statements. So keep after it.

Now, I want to bother you about a little
professional information. In the Feb. '46
issue of the Reeder's Digest, Paul de Kruif
has an article about the wonderful
results of prostigmin in relieving the
spasticity in various forms of spastic
paralysis and even in some forms of
arthritis. As the spacticity which I still
have is mythe only thing that bothers me, I
would like to know what you people think
of it. I have never seen the things which
de Kruif has written about live up to his
landatory reports, so I have more or less
discredited him. How the profession feels about
him I dont know. If there is anything in
his claims about prostigmin I would like
to give it a trial, unless there are contraindications
to its use. de Kruif never mentions things
which interfere with the use of the drugs
II
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
he lauds to the skies so highly.

I asked Hillman, at the Letterman,
about it and he did not know-
further, he has no one who is up
on such things. The Letterman is now
almost entirely a surgical outfit.

I am in fine shape and really feel
fine. I still have trouble with my leg
and relief from the spasticity would
practically relieve me of all trouble
I dont think that any of my brain cells were destroyed
Any information you can give me
on the subject would therefore be
much appreciated.

From what I can learn the A.M.A.
will meet here in S.F. in July (1-5)
So it is nice to know that you
are scheduled to be present. It will
be fine to see you out here again.
Plan to stay an extra day to talk
with me about Y.F. There are still
plenty of things to mull over.

My son Jack is in Tokyo. He graduated
from West Point last June. He is one
of the officers on Mac A's staff on Counter
Intelligence work. He enjoys it
AC
T
my oldest daughter is now living
with us. She has been in Washington
for 10 yrs. and we are delighted to have
her home again.

With best wishes for you and
your charming family
